author: Odeinoichus
title: Inspirational Fun in the Land of Oo.
review:
Set #71246 Adventure Time Team Pack: Why not come along to join all your friends and have some fun where the Adventure never ends? Finn the Human gets to team up with his best pal Jake the Dog and Lumpy Space Princess once you pick up this two-pack for LEGO Dimensions:

Packaging

I started discussing the instructions in previous Series 2 Reviews, but had phased out that conversation during Series 1. So let’s just say that the instructions are the same as they’ve always been in these packs and move on.

Jake and LSP are on the front of the box in large artwork showing off the two characters that will join you in LEGO Dimensions. The rest of the package is identical to past Team Packs and looks great when put next to the rest of the collection on the wall. Or on a shelf or somewhere you might keep packaging if you collect and display it.

Parts

This set has some very nice sand green elements for BMO, including two very rare sausage elements in a shade of sand green that looks great. Though perhaps not edible, unless they are from some animal in the Star Wars universe. Overall a great set for parts much like most other Dimensions packs, which makes them worth picking up for the parts alone.

Minifigures

Jake the Dog: Jake has a unique head piece and short legs with a torso printed with minor detailing for the character. It is an interesting looking Minifigure and carries a flashlight for an accessory.

Lumpy Space Princess: A unique sculpted piece is used for LSP similar to Slimer from Ghostbusters. Being one solid piece with printed detailing for the face on the front. She has a cell phone printed tile and her Toy Tag is very in keeping with her overall look.

The build

BMO: This is essentially another buildable character and the build is designed to match the animation model. It’s much different from what you built in the Ideas set. For one thing this model is much smaller.

DOGMO: This alternate build takes the game console character and turns it into a strangely shaped looking creature. It’s a nice re-use of parts.

SNAKEMO: Here the snake shows us a third and final alternative build for the game console character takes a strange twist as he is now built into a snake-like looking console. It’s a rather unusual build for the parts being used, but it works as the steps are easy enough to follow along with.

Lumpy Car: LSP gets to ride around in style in this very fun little model. You build it quickly and with very little difficulty, it kind of reminds me of the Care Bear Cloud Cars from the 80’s cartoon in design and build, but isn’t meant to be.

Lumpy Truck: Break apart your open-air car and rebuild it into this model. Using all the same parts this model is fairly intuitive and extremely fun as an alternative build.

Lumpy Land Whale: In comparison this model is a bit confusing and a little too busy in my opinion, but the build is easy to follow along with and works as best as it can for re-using the elements in the main model in this secondary form.

The completed model

BMO & Alternative Models: All three of these models look quirky and fun, while BMO is from the cartoon, I am uncertain if DOGMO and SNAKEMO appear in any episodes. Each of the models however stands out as unique and very impressive in design and playability. DOGMO even has studs on top so you can attach Jake if you’d care to.

Lumpy Car & Alternative Models: LSP’s models, in comparison, are vehicle based and look great. You can also attach LSP to her car and the land whale models using the 1x2 clear brick she uses to attach to things. I feel the Lumpy Car and Truck are stronger in design compared to the Land Whale, but at least the Land Whale looks like a whale.

The Digital Content

The Adventure World: You can unlock Adventure Time world with this Team Pack, so if you wanted to skip the level pack this team pack would work better as far as price ranges go.

Battle Arena: Both characters in a Team Pack unlock the Battle Arena, which is known as Adventure Time Breakfast World. Again I don’t have much experience with the multiplayer levels, but they are an excellent addition to the game, if cause for some disappointment due to load times and some game crashes.

Character & Vehicle Abilities: Jake is loaded with abilities, he can Target, Sonar Smash, use Gyrosphere Switches, Super Strength Handles, Done Mazes, Drill, Illumination, Grapple, Mini Access, Slurp Access, Tracking, Dive, Big Transform and can Destroy Cracked LEGO Objects. That is again a lot of abilities, which is mostly because Jake can alter his form much like he does on-screen. His Big Transform is the Jakesuit, which allows other characters to wear Jake like a big suit, which again is very impressive.

LSP shares a few abilities with Jake. She can Mini and Slurp Access and Target, the other abilities are unique to her, Boomerang, Hazard Protection and Rainbow LEGO Objects. Which means she can destroy and build with Rainbow bricks just like Unikitty from Series 1.

BMO can access BMO Docks which allow you to play little video game adventures inside a virtual world, he (or she) also has the Guardian Ability and the Illumination skill. DOGMO gains the ability to Dig. SNAKEMO can use Electricity Switches.

The Lumpy Car can use Accelerator Switches, the Tow-Bar ability and can Jump. The Lumpy Truck can use the Tow-Bar, Flight Docks, Flight Cargo Hooks and can Destroy Gold and Rainbow LEGO Objects. Lumpy Land Whale is capable of using Underwater Drone, underwater Interactions and Sonar Smash.

Overall opinion

Adventure Time Team Pack is an interesting companion piece to the Level Pack. It gives you two more characters from the universe in question with two more vehicle builds and has a lot of character interactions when these people talk together on the Toy Pad. Overall though, the Level Pack is really the only one needed to access everything.

Although you can’t unlock the Battle Arena without these characters, so most of Series 2 is going to be must own if you want to explore all of the Battle Arenas. I’d recommend this set to fans of the series, and for folks interested in owning a complete Dimensions Series for their gaming toy shelves. Recommended.
